;;B;;物质生命;变化惊人。这些单细胞生物有球体、棒状、螺旋状和螺旋状。有的有一厘米长；有的有一厘米长。大多数都小数万倍。它们在珠穆朗玛峰、南极洲和地壳深处被发现。然而，几乎所有发现的细菌物种都有一个特征：其成员不喜欢独居。

;
;;
;

;蒙大拿州立大学的微生物学家 Matthew Fields 认为，大多数生活在地球上的细菌以菌落形式存在。这些粘稠的聚集体被称为生物膜，由从死亡邻居细胞中回收的<小>;DNA;链、蛋白质和其他分子结合在一起。这种社交性是古老的。地球上一些已知最古老的生命证据是被称为叠层石的生物膜化石。西澳大利亚州的一组叠层石被认为已有 35 亿年的历史。

;

;同居带来了巨大的好处。当生物膜变得足够大时，敌对方就很难渗透。一些估计表明，这些堡垒可以使抗生素清除细菌的难度提高 1,000 倍。但对细菌来说是福音，但对许多必须与它们生活在一起的人类却是祸根。 2022 年的数据表明，生物膜在 60% 的人类细菌感染中发挥着作用。它们聚集在关节植入物上并堵塞导管。它们栖息在医院的床栏、电灯开关和保温箱中。它们会感染开放性伤口，并在牙齿之间产生牙菌斑。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;2017年，英国国家生物膜创新中心将生物膜的全球经济负担列为超过 3.9 万亿美元。这不仅仅意味着健康成本。生物膜可以;腐蚀金属;并污染基础设施。

;

;尽管问题规模很大，但很少引起关注。原因之一是人们对生物膜的了解相对较少。几种不同种类的细菌可以结合在一个生物膜中，这使得在实验室中创建准确的模型变得更加困难。尽管如此，我们正在取得进展。对生物膜的更好理解正在指明消除它们的方法。

;

;没有两个生物膜是完全相同的。但当细菌通常被食物吸引到达表面时，它们就开始了。它分泌粘性化合物来附着自身并开始分裂。对于繁殖最快的菌株来说，几天之内或几个小时之内，一小群后代就形成了。

;

;在菌群内部

;

;新细菌和任何感兴趣的路人可以通过多种方式将自己附着在菌落上。这些包括细菌分泌的聚合物。 <小>;DNA;分子通常携带生物体的遗传信息，但细菌可以将它们重新用作生化胶。伦敦帝国理工学院的细菌学家蒂亚戈·科斯塔 (Tiago Costa) 在《自然通讯》四月份发表的一篇论文中报告说，细菌用来交换遗传信息的接合菌毛（毛发状细丝）同样可以被重新利用以结合他们在一起。

;

;细菌还可以利用它们在环境中发现的其他化学物质构建路障。例如，活体中的生物膜有时会利用宿主的免疫系统。当白细胞发现细菌感染时，它们有时会释放一串胞外<小>;DNA;来封锁它。但这往往会适得其反，帮助生物膜粘合在一起。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;生物膜构建由群体感应控制，群体感应是细菌交换的过程化学信息来计算出附近有多少同伴，并相应地调整他们的行为。最终的结果就像是一种特设的多细胞生物体，由数十亿个细菌和运动通道组成，可以携带营养物质并清除废物。哥本哈根大学的研究人员在《通讯生物学》9 月 1 日发表的一篇论文中发现，有时生物膜甚至不需要固体表面即可形成。相反，它的成员可以附着在漂浮在液体介质中的其他细菌上——科斯塔博士说，这相当于游牧部落的细菌，而不是固定的定居点。

;

;这种凝聚力使得生物膜比生物膜更难移动。个别细菌会。生物膜保护其大部分成员免受抗生素和免疫细胞的侵害，而抗生素和免疫细胞很难穿透其外层。生物膜最深处的细菌可以进入类似冬眠的状态，其中它们的新陈代谢大大减慢。这使得这些所谓的“持久者”寿命更长，并且对任何依赖破坏细菌细胞化学作用发挥作用的抗生素具有更强的抵抗力。当受到攻击时，一些生物膜甚至会脱落，在身体其他部位播下新的感染种子。

;

;所有这些都构成了挑战。 “这就像堑壕战，”科斯塔博士说。 “我们不是在与一种细菌作战，我们是在与一支军队作战。”大部分武器都是简陋的：清洁开放性伤口、开抗生素，或者在植入物受感染的情况下，将其移除、消毒并放回原处。

;

;但武器库正在增长。一种有前途的武器是;噬菌体;。这些病毒以与许多细菌感染其他生物体相同的方式感染细菌。与抗生素一样，噬菌体不会影响宿主细胞。与抗生素不同的是，它们在杀死猎物的过程中会产生更多的自身作用。这意味着即使最初的剂量很小，也可以发展成一支足够强大的敌方军队来袭击细菌路障。人们认为，细菌更难像对许多药物那样进化出对噬菌体的抵抗力，因为噬菌体本身可以进化来对抗新的防御。

;

;噬菌体在一些实验室研究中已被证明是有效的，但缺乏数据阻碍了商业药物的问世。这种情况正在改变。总部位于格拉斯哥的固定噬菌体公司是众多试图开发针对生物膜的噬菌体的公司之一。该公司正在开发一种用于狗牙齿的产品，以防止蛀牙并消除口臭。它希望很快能够超越犬科动物，并测试噬菌体对抗人类糖尿病足感染的能力。

;

;贝尔法斯特女王大学的微生物学家布伦丹·吉尔莫尔正在研究冷等离子体，这是一种电子被剥夺的物质。它们的母原子是通过强大的电场而不是灼热的温度。尽管生物膜可以在暴露于血浆的情况下幸存下来，但吉尔莫尔博士和他的团队认为，压力可以促进“持久性”的新陈代谢，足以恢复它们对抗生素的脆弱性。

;

;与此同时，匹兹堡的一家名为 Peptilogics 的生物技术公司，正在探索消灭正在冬眠的细菌的方法。它正在试验一种名为 ;PLG;0206 的小蛋白质，该蛋白质会被生物膜内的带负电荷的环境所吸引。一旦到达那里，它就可以破坏细菌细胞的膜，无论其活性水平如何。对 14 名人工关节感染患者进行的 1 期临床试验于 2022 年 10 月开始。中期数据看起来很有希望。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;有些人不希望找到进入堡垒的方法，而是希望将其拆除。 2008年，当时在南加州大学工作的史蒂文·古德曼（Steven Goodman）和他在俄亥俄州立大学的合作者劳伦·巴卡莱茨（Lauren Bakaletz）发现了生物膜的两个通用组成部分——可以用正确的工具松开的标准螺钉。所讨论的螺丝是 ;DNAB;II 家族中的两种蛋白质（发音为 ;DNA;-;B;-2）。它们与 ;DNA; 支架交叉的位置结合。除去它们，生物膜就会崩溃。

;

;在过去的 15 年里，他们已经用超过 20 种细菌测试了他们的理论，其中包括导致结核病和麻风病的细菌。 ;DNAB;II 消失后，没有生物膜幸存下来。这两位研究人员现在担任 Clarametyx 的科学委员会主席，Clarametyx 是一家位于俄亥俄州的生物技术公司，旨在将他们的发现转化为临床产品。

;

;Clarametyx 正在开发 ;CMTX;-101，这是一种用于从生物膜中去除两种 ;DNAB;II 蛋白之一的药物。该药物是一种抗体，由小鼠接触目标蛋白时产生的类似抗体改编而成，适合人类使用。 Clarametyx 希望有一天静脉注射 ;CMTX;-101 可以与抗生素一起使用。首次针对肺炎患者的人体试验于 2022 年 11 月开始。预计结果将于 2024 年初公布。该公司希望尽快开始针对囊性纤维化患者的试验。

;

;另一家追求同样目标的生物技术公司是总部位于加利福尼亚州的 Trellis Biosciences。他们没有在实验室中开发 DNAB II 靶向抗体，而是寻找人类中已经存在的抗体。经过三年的测试，他们鉴定出了一种名为 ;TRL;1068 的抗体，与 Clarametyx 的分子一样，可以从生物膜中提取 ;DNAB;II 蛋白。当对感染 MRSA（一种对多种抗生素具有抗药性的细菌）生物膜的小鼠进行测试时，它们使抗生素功效提高了 1,000 倍。该公司总裁 Stefan Ryser 表示：“我们正在让传统抗生素再次发挥作用。”

;

;拆除工作

;

;5 月份，该公司公布了对 8 名慢性病患者进行的 1 期试验结果假体关节感染。六个月后，没有一名患者出现重复感染，其中两名患者的植入物上根本没有显示出生物膜的迹象。特雷利斯现在计划进行更大规模的试验。

;

;现在说这些方法中哪一种（如果有的话）可能会产生有用的药物还为时过早。但随着细菌不断进化出对抗生素的耐药性，生物膜带来的问题只会越来越严重。 “我认为这个领域有容纳多个参与者的空间，”Clarametyx 的老板戴夫·理查兹 (Dave Richards) 说。加入的公司越多，其中一家提出革命性成果的机会就越大。 ;■;

;

;;过去;;或几年;微软一直在试图哄办公室员工写报告、填充数据使用其办公软件制作电子表格并创建幻灯片。不再：现在它想为他们进行写作和填充。在其位于西雅图绿树成荫的郊区雷德蒙德的总部，该公司展示了其最新的魔法。平板玻璃窗外，雪山闪闪发光，松树摇曳。在内部，一个灰色的小矩形位于空白 Word 文档的顶部。只需几句指令，由人工智能（;AI;）（微软称之为“Copilot”）驱动的聊天机器人就会在计算机文件夹中找到一个巨大的文件并总结其内容。随后，它编辑了自己的作品并简洁地回答了有关材料的问题。它还可以执行许多其他技巧：挖掘有关某些主题的电子邮件，根据会议制定待办事项列表，甚至制作有关您的通讯员的尚可的 PowerPoint 演示文稿。

;
;;
;

;这是对未来工作的一瞥。 “生成式”人工智能的令人难以置信的能力似乎将改变许多办公桌工作。这也是对微软未来的一瞥，微软曾经是世界上最有价值的上市公司，并希望通过销售推动转型的技术来重新夺回这一头衔。通过该公司对 Open;AI;（流行的 ;AI; 聊天机器人 Chat;GPT; 背后的初创公司）的投资，它能够注入尖端的; >;人工智能;融入其产品。

;

;Pilot鲸鱼

;

;这不仅仅意味着将Copilot添加到其办公软件（以前称为“Office”，但最近更名）称为“Microsoft 365”），将于 11 月推出。本周，该公司将推出其操作系统 Copilot for Windows，它将能够更改计算机的设置、生成图像和汇总网页。其销售软件和人力资源产品的副驾驶已经可用。一款安全软件正在开发中。二月份，微软在其搜索引擎 Bing 中添加了类似于 Chat;GPT; 的功能，这实际上是另一个 Copilot。凭借其副驾驶中队，微软正在将生成式 ;AI; 融入其业务的几乎各个方面。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;这可能是任何公司在;AI;上所下的最大赌注。奖金可能是巨大的。 Copilots 可以改变 12 亿 Microsoft 365 用户和 14 亿 Windows 用户的工作世界。这将使微软能够吸引新客户并向他们收取更高的费用。反过来，这可能会推动微软高利润云业务 Azure 的业务发展，并可能帮助其超越亚马逊网络服务 (;AWS;)，成为全球最大的云公司。它甚至可能帮助微软的估值高于当前的 2.3 万亿美元，从而有可能缩小与目前全球市值最高公司苹果公司的差距（见图 1）。经纪人 Mark Moerdler 认为，事实上，人工智能为微软提供了一个诱人的机会，可以做一些迄今为止一直未能实现的事情，并将其提供的所有功能整合在一起。微软的视频会议服务 Teams 可能比竞争对手 Zoom 更能吸引 IT 经理，如果它配备了一个可以在 Outlook 中整理员工电子邮件并从 Word 文档中调出信息的 Copilot和幻灯片。所有这些魔法都可以通过 Azure 实现，从而进一步推动微软的业务。

;

;尽管如此，微软也下了一场豪赌。明年其资本支出预计将增加近五分之二，达到约 400 亿美元。这占该公司收入的 16% 接近创纪录的水平，比除 Facebook 母公司 Meta 之外的任何其他科技巨头都要高。其中大部分将用于新的<小>;人工智能;芯片和高性能网络，以进入其计划上线的 120 多个额外数据中心。这样的投资是否会带来回报是一个悬而未决的问题。尽管副驾驶做出了所有承诺，但他们仍然面临很多问题。在雷德蒙德的演示中，;AI; 生成的幻灯片将您的通讯员描述为“;ABC; Inc 的;CEO;”，但他绝对不是。竞争对手，尤其是 Alphabet（谷歌的母公司），正在关注所有相同的市场。随着未来工作之争的白热化，微软的地位令人羡慕，但并非无懈可击。

;

;将自己置于这一地位是经过长期努力的。微软的全盛时期是 20 世纪 90 年代。 Windows 作为操作系统的主导地位与残酷的商业心态相结合，使该公司变得强大但遭到全面鄙视。随后经历了一段停滞期，因为它依靠 Windows 的收入生存。 2014 年萨蒂亚·纳德拉 (Satya Nadella) 上任后，他彻底改变了现状。 Windows 将不再是公司的主要关注点。相反，该公司围绕 Azure 进行了重组，将 Office 等热门项目转向云。这涉及到数据中心的大规模扩建。微软的资本支出占收入的比例从 2014 年的 6% 上升到五年后的 11%。至关重要的是，该公司放弃了围墙花园的做法。纳德拉先生允许微软的软件在其他操作系统上运行，例如谷歌、苹果和 Linux（Windows 的开源竞争对手）。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;微软一直在投资;人工智能;。它于 2016 年首次宣布与 Open;AI; 合作；此后，该公司已投资 130 亿美元，据报道持有 49% 的股份。该交易不仅允许微软使用Open;AI;的技术，还规定Open;AI;的模型和工具在Azure上运行，实际上使Open; AI的客户变成了微软的间接客户。而且它不仅仅是开放;AI;。自纳德拉接任以来，微软已经收购了 15 家<小>;人工智能;相关公司。其中包括在 2022 年斥资 200 亿美元收购拥有尖端语音转文本技术的医疗保健公司 Nuance。

;
;;

;如今，微软的业务增长依赖于三个部门。第一个是蔚蓝。在过去的五年里，它一直在逼近 ;AWS;（参见图 2）。随着;IT;经理收紧钱包，云支出正在放缓。尽管如此，最近一个季度的业务同比增长了27%。微软没有透露Azure的销售额，但分析师认为它约占该公司收入的四分之一，去年该公司收入达到2120亿美元。其云业务的毛利率也是秘密，但 Bernstein 认为毛利率高达 60% 左右。

;

;其次是 Microsoft 365，它也占收入的四分之一左右。由于小型企业，尤其是餐馆等服务行业的采用，这一数字最近每年增长约 10%。第三个增长源是网络安全。微软高管在财报电话会议上表示，该公司的收入约为 200 亿美元（约占总收入的十分之一）。这比仅提供网络安全的五家最大公司的收入总和还要多。更重要的是，收入每年增长约 30%。 （微软的视频游戏部门每年带来 150 亿美元的收入，现在英国反垄断监管机构已表示将批准以 690 亿美元收购另一家游戏制造商动视暴雪 (Activision Blizzard) 的交易，该交易拖延已久。） p>;

;

;蓝色微调器

;

;使用Azure作为微软其他业务的底层基础设施有助于分摊成本、简化运营并提高利润。自 2014 年以来，营业利润率从 29% 上升至 43%，高于其他科技巨头（见图 3）。这让投资者兴奋不已。在纳德拉先生任职期间，微软的市值增长了约 2 万美元。微软的市盈率（表明投资者对未来利润的预期）在纳德拉执政期间增加了一倍多，达到 32。这高于 ;S;&;P < /small>;平均水平为 500，超过了除亚马逊之外的所有科技巨头，亚马逊的数字因微薄的收入而扭曲。

;
;;

;啦啦队表示，微软在生成;AI;方面有两大优势。首先是它销售的软件范围。要求单个聊天机器人仔细阅读电子邮件和电子表格以制作幻灯片放映比为每个程序处理不同的;AI;助手要容易得多。

;

;其次，微软有一个先行者优势。由于与 Chat;GPT; 的合作，它比竞争对手更快地部署;AI;，也可能是因为纳德拉先生认为它对智能手机和人工智能的反应缓慢。云。不管出于什么原因，微软的速度使得 Open;AI; 成为大公司尝试该技术的默认选择。摩根大通银行最近对 ;IT; 经理进行的一项调查发现，未来三年，他们预计在生成 ;AI; 方面的支出将有 56% 流向微软，而;AWS; 为 13%，Google Cloud Platform (;GCP;) 为 12%。

;

;风险投资公司红杉资本对 33 家初创公司进行的另一项调查其投资的公司发现，其中 90% 使用 Open;AI;。摩根士丹利银行的 Keith Weiss 认为，围绕 Open;AI; 的 ;GPT;-4 模型的生态系统正在开始形成。其中包括专门研究其工具并建议客户使用这些工具的顾问，以及 HubSpot 等软件销售商，该销售商使用 Open;AI; 的模型构建定制程序。

;

; 有一些证据表明 Copilots 可以帮助巩固微软的领先地位。 2022 年 6 月，它在 GitHub 上推出了代码生成 Copilot，这是微软在 2018 年以 75 亿美元收购的代码存储库。该模型是使用 GitHub 上存储的大量代码进行训练的。它已迅速成为软件开发人员的必备工具。在一项调查中，90% 的用户告诉 GitHub，Copilot 提高了他们的工作效率。该公司还进行了一项小型研究，发现使用该工具时，程序员完成任务的速度提高了 55%。约有 27,000 家企业订阅了该服务，数量是三个月前的两倍。它在科技圈如此流行，以至于“copilot”一词已成为 ;AI; 助手的简写，无论是否由 Microsoft 提供。

;
;
;
;< div id="econ-3">;
;
;
;

;微软表示，公司正在测试 Copilot 的“生产力”软件（即用于电子邮件、电子表格、文字处理等） ）报告类似的好处。电信公司 Lumen 的老板凯特·约翰逊 (Kate Johnson) 将其描述为员工工作方式的“阶跃功能变化”。她用它来回顾 Teams 会议，看看是否给安静的员工提供了发言的机会。它还可以即时记录并为与会者制定待办事项列表。约翰逊女士补充道，这有助于问责制：员工在上次会议后要完成的任务“就在那里，每个人都可以看到”。

;

;副驾驶还可以充当软件教练，教员工如何插入例如，电子表格中的图表。目标是他们最终能够了解用户的偏好，甚至他们的写作风格。纳德拉在 2017 年出版的《Hit Refresh》一书中写道：“我们希望有一天能够提供一个高效的另一个自我——一个深入了解你的代理人。”。

;

;这一切的代价并不便宜。按照每位用户每月 30 美元的价格，Copilots 可能意味着 52-83% 的加价，具体取决于公司使用的软件包。研究公司 Gartner 的杰森·黄 (Jason Wong) 表示：“与许可证相比，这很昂贵，但如果它能每周为您节省时间，那就便宜了。”

;

;微软从 Copilots 赚钱的另一种方式是来自底层基础设施。 5 月份，它宣布在 Azure 上推出“Copilot Stack”。这使得开发人员可以轻松地在自己的应用程序中构建 Copilots 或为 Microsoft 的 Copilots 创建“插件”。希望许多公司使用此基础设施，向 Azure 发送更多业务。这种“平台”方法的另一个优点是，微软可能能够达成交易，使用 Azure 客户的数据，将法律专业知识引入 Word 文档或电子邮件中。伯恩斯坦的一份研究报告指出，这创造了一种“竞争对手将发现非常难以或不可能复制”的优势。

;

;Hammerhead

;

;今年第二季度;AI; 为微软的云收入增加了约 1.2 亿美元。预计本季度将翻一番。 Weiss 先生估计，到 2025 年，;ai; 的收入可能会增加 400 亿美元，这主要是通过 Azure 的 ;AI; 工具和 365 的 Copilots 实现的。

;

;这样的增长不会是便宜的。股票市场分析师公司 New Street Research 认为，微软是全球最大的人工智能芯片销售商英伟达的最大客户。其研究表明，微软在 2023 年第二季度在 Nvidia 的 AI 芯片上花费了约 30 亿美元，高于第一季度的约 10 亿美元。在 7 月份与投资者的电话会议中，首席财务官艾米·胡德 (Amy Hood) 指出，人工智能的发展正在给微软在云领域的浮夸利润带来压力。她说，这可以通过更高效的数据处理来抵消。微软云和;AI;主管 Scott Guthrie 表示：“我们看到推理成本[与向 ;AI; 模型提出问题相关的成本]正在下降，并预计会看到继续下去，模型会变得更加准确和高效。”

;

;即使不断上升的成本得到控制，仍然存在很多其他风险。竞争已经白热化。一场争夺价值 3400 亿美元的商业软件市场的战争。 5 月，谷歌发布了 Duet for Workspace，它的 Copilots 版本。上周，该公司发布了允许其聊天机器人 Bard 访问用户 Gmail 收件箱和 Google 文档的功能。软件巨头Salesforce拥有爱因斯坦。 Slack 是一款消息应用程序，也是 Salesforce 的子公司之一，拥有 Slack ;GPT;。 ServiceNow 的软件可以帮助公司管理他们的工作流程，它有 Now Assist。 Zoom 提供 Zoom Companion。 Intuit 正在销售 Intuit Assist。 Adept 和 Cohere 等初创公司也提供人工智能助手。 Open;AI; 于 8 月推出了以企业为中心的 Chat;GPT;。

;

;提供基础设施来支撑此类 ;ai; 产品将由另一个战场。 ;AWS; 和 ;GCP; 都提供对类似于 Open;AI; 的 ;AI; 模型的访问。分析师怀疑这些竞争对手在部署专业<小>;人工智能;芯片方面比微软更有经验。 8 月，谷歌推出了一款用于训练大型模型的新型 ;AI; 芯片。

;
;;

;所有生成;AI;工具，包括Copilots，也必须“为企业做好准备” ”，微软大投资者 T. Rowe Price 的肯·艾伦 (Ken Allen) 说道。其中一个问题是合法的。大多数;AI;模型都是根据受版权保护的材料进行训练的，用户可能会无意中复制这些材料。一家大型石油和天然气服务公司的 IT 负责人表示，在公司于 11 月份因侵犯版权而被起诉后，他阻止员工使用 GitHub 的 Copilot。微软方面已同意支付客户与其副驾驶相关的法律费用，前提是他们使用微软的安全功能，例如内容过滤器。

;

;模型也可能出错。微软通过对他们进行准确、最新信息的培训以及增加引用来减少此类问题。但这并没有阻止您的记者晋升为;首席执行官;。负责微软生产力软件的 Jared Spataro 表示，Copilots 带来了一种“全新的工作方式”，机器可以帮助你生产更多的东西，“但它并不总是正确的”。人们必须对此保持警惕，并在必要时进行纠正。

;

;第三个问题是数据治理——确保只有合适的员工才能访问正确的信息。一位分析师指出，Copilots 的一些早期用户发现了“非常可怕”的结果。例如，想象一下搜索中出现的人事文件或机密电子邮件。

;

;几乎可以肯定的是，微软将被指控滥用其市场力量。 （在 20 世纪 90 年代末期，无休止的竞争问题一直困扰着它之前的崛起时期。）该公司已经在许多方面展开了斗争。 8 月，在 Slack 的投诉引发;欧盟;调查后，该公司宣布将从其软件包中“分拆”Teams。客户还抱怨微软的软件许可证促使公司使用 Azure，而不是 ;AWS; 和 ;GCP;。微软总裁布拉德史密斯称这是“合理的担忧”，该公司表示已经做出了改变。但今年 6 月，谷歌向美国联邦贸易委员会的调查提交了评论，声称微软使用不公平的许可条款来“锁定客户”。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;此类纠纷无疑会随着;人工智能驱动的软件变得流行。例如，如果 Windows Copilot 将用户引导至 Outlook 而不是 Gmail，那么反垄断者可能会大喊大叫。这样做的结果可能会削弱微软利用广泛的软件产品使 Copilots 更有用的能力，这是其巨大的竞争优势之一。

;

;即便如此，微软仍处于强势地位。它未能抓住智能手机的出现，也未能及时抓住云的潜力。如今，它发现自己已准备好利用一项可以改变工作世界的技术。它必须保持微妙的平衡，比竞争对手更快地行动，同时确保其进军人工智能领域不会令监管机构感到不安、削弱利润或激怒客户。如果它下滑，许多竞争对手已经准备好取代它。但如果成功的话，回报将是巨大的。副驾驶将成为其命运的船长。 ;■;

; Fri, 29 Sep 2023 19:57:02 +0800 Why there is a bear market in rhinos | Middle East & Africahttps://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/09/26/why-there-is-a-bear-market-in-rhinos ;
;< /div>;

;;;;需要多少;人才能移动一头犀牛？记者怀疑答案是“你能找到的尽可能多的”。最近的一个早晨，在南非面积最大的省份北开普省，一名兽医从直升机上向一头雌性犀牛的臀部发射了镇静剂飞镖。随后，19 名护林员用一根电棒和大量围栏才将这只厚皮动物放进板条箱。一旦进入动物体内，它就会被卡车运到它的新主人，另一个私人野生动物保护区。

;
;;
;
;;

;买卖活犀牛并不是一件容易的事。如今，这也不是一件有利可图的事情。斯泰伦博斯大学的海莉·克莱门茨 (Hayley Clements) 表示，2019 年南方白犀牛的平均价格比十年前低了近 70%（见图表）。如今，一头雄性犀牛的售价约为 150,000 兰特（7,900 美元）。今年早些时候，拥有 2,000 头南方白猫（约占全球野生种群 15%）的主人约翰·休姆 (John Hume) 在出售这些白猫时没有收到任何出价。非洲公园 (African Parks) 是一个由国际捐助者资助的非自然保护组织，介入以低于其要价的一小部分购买犀牛。

;

;犀牛的熊市最终与经济有关。称之为号角法则。南部白猫是最常见的品种，是南非的成功故事。它被猎杀到几乎被遗忘的地步。到 1929 年，只剩下 150 人。自然资源保护主义者伊恩·普莱尔 (Ian Player) 于 1960 年发起“犀牛行动”，通过将犀牛从国家公园分配到私人保护区来恢复数量。

;

;在 20 世纪 80 年代引入犀牛拍卖以及在 90 年代加强对动物的所有权之后，进一步的增长出现了。两者都提高了保护它们的经济激励措施。牛津大学的迈克尔·特·萨斯·罗尔夫斯 (Michael 't Sas-Rolfes) 认为，“创建产权和市场制度是游戏规则的改变者”。如今，南非一半以上的南部白人在私人土地上放牧。

;

;保护区所有者通过旅游业和狩猎赚钱。后者冒犯了许多人，但向来自科茨沃尔德或康涅狄格州的牙医收取假冒欧内斯特·海明威的费用，使许多储备得以维持。由于每年被猎杀的数十头犀牛都是老公牛，否则它们会争夺资源，因此规范狩猎实际上有助于增加数量。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;然而，在过去的 15 年里，犀牛已经变成了从资产变成负债。主要原因是保护它们免遭偷猎的成本。南非南部白犀牛的数量在 2010 年达到 18,796 头（约占全球总数的 80%），到 2021 年下降至 12,968 头。大多数在国营公园被猎杀。

;

;少于每年偷猎造成的损失中有 10% 发生在私人土地上。这是因为私人业主在安全方面的支出至少是国家公园的四倍。他们无法转嫁所有费用：狩猎爱好者可以选择海滩。 “犀牛所有权的经济学是一场灾难。这是一个无底洞，”游说团体私人犀牛所有者协会负责人佩勒姆琼斯说。

;

;还有非财务成本。 “有很多令人心痛的事情，”兽医兼保护区所有者彼得·奥贝伦 (Peter Oberem) 说。 2008年，他发现了一位死去的女族长，她的脸被斧头砍伤；她一个月大的孩子正在绝望地尝试吃奶。他和他的妻子抚养了小牛。 “他现在是个大混蛋了，”奥伯伦先生自豪地说。但压力和成本对某些人来说太大了。据该协会称，过去 15 年里，犀牛保护区的数量从 330 头减少到 280 头。

;

;人们正在采取许多创造性的努力来增加犀牛的数量。非洲公园组织由捐助者资助的转运到其他非洲国家。去年，世界银行发行了第一批“犀牛债券”，为南非两个国有黑犀牛公园筹集资金。另一个想法是“生物多样性信用”，它将支付给那些保护动植物的人。

;

;犀牛所有者认为，最简单的解决方案是使犀牛角国际贸易合法化。犀牛一年可长出1-1.5公斤的角。那些被砍掉鼻子的动物在短短几年内就会再次露出尖尖的鼻子。这意味着即使在偷猎高峰期，业主也可以持续向市场提供比目前更多的犀牛角。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;然而去年;CITES;的签署国，一项国际条约，维持了自 1977 年以来实施的禁令。其支持者坚持认为，合法化将创造比通过合法供应所能满足的更多的需求，因此最好通过彻底的禁令来抑制需求。事实上，自 1977 年以来偷猎活动激增，表明禁令对需求影响甚微。

;

;最重要的是，业主不愿意由外人告诉他们该做什么。 “我认为自己是一个新手，但后来我遇到了这些新手，他们不知道自己在说什么，”奥贝伦先生说。他和其他人谈到了一些来自富裕国家的非政府组织和规则制定者的“殖民”做法。 (Perhaps if most owners of southern whites were not southern whites themselves, they would make for more formidable foes of the self-styled progressives in global conservation.)

;

;Ultimately conservation is expensive. Sometimes the costs can be met through philanthropy or from taxpayers funding national parks. Yet such is the current logic of the horn laws: the animals are worth more dead than alive. ;■;

; Fri, 29 Sep 2023 07:27:03 +0800 What happens if America’s government shuts down this weekend? | The Economist explainshttps://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2023/09/27/what-happens-if-americas-government-shuts-down-this-weekend ;
;
;

;;O;;N SEPTEMBER 26TH ;American lawmakers returned to Washington, ;DC;, with yet another government shutdown looming.联邦财政年度于 10 月 1 日开始，但国会尚未拨款维持政府运转所需的资金。参议院批准了一项两党法案，该法案将阻止政府关门直至 11 月 17 日。但共和党众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡似乎不太可能说服党内的极右翼成员投票支持权宜之计。 9 月 22 日，白宫命令联邦机构为十年来第四次关闭做好准备。 What happens when America's government shuts down?

;

;Parts of it will keep running.退伍军人事务部管理的医院为数百万人提供护理，但仍然开放。邮件投递：美国邮政服务的资金来自邮票和服务收入，而不是拨款的税款。在机场检查乘客的警察、武装部队成员、空中交通管制员和运输安全管理局员工都在继续工作。但是，就像“休假”（即被告知不要上班）的联邦工作人员一样，他们没有得到报酬。上一次关闭始于 2018 年 12 月 22 日，持续了 35 天，之后国会通过了一项法律，保证休假工人的欠薪，当时这些工人占 210 万非邮政联邦劳动力中的 80 万人。 But extended shutdowns will still strain federal workers' pocketbooks.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Some parts of the state will strip back their operations.例如，社会保障（养老金）和医疗保险的受益人仍应收到支票，尽管新申请人可能需要等待注册，并且某些付款可能会延迟。但随着各机构耗尽储存的资金，其他联邦职能要么立即停止，要么最终停止。

;

;In previous shutdowns, for example, the Environmental Protection Agency halted inspections of chemical facilities and drinking-water providers, as well as of sites that handle hazardous waste.美国食品药品监督管理局可能会停止检查屠宰场和其他食品生产场所。各州必须承担联邦福利计划的义务。长期关闭可能会导致食品券支付停止，从而增加贫困家庭挨饿的风险。国家公园可能会继续开放，但服务大幅减少。已经紧张的移民法庭可能难以运作； people may be unable to take out home or business loans that require federal approval.

;

; Fri, 29 Sep 2023 07:27:03 +0800 China is flooding Taiwan with disinformation | Asiahttps://www.economist.com/asia/2023/09/26/china-is-flooding-taiwan-with-disinformation ;
;
;

;;I;;n July one; of Taiwan's top newspapers, ;United Daily News;, published a story based on supposedly leaked minutes from a secret government meeting. America had asked ;Taiwan; to make biological weapons at a lab run by the island's defence ministry, the report claimed. Taiwanese and American officials denied it. The allegedly leaked minutes, it transpired, were not written in the usual style of Taiwanese government records. They were filled with official-sounding phrases that are used in mainland China, but not in Taiwan.

;
;;
;

;This was probably Chinese disinformation, Taiwanese officials said. Yet the story spread to Taiwanese talk shows and influencers. It soon evolved into a wilder claim: Taiwan was going to collect 150,000 samples of Taiwanese blood and hand them to the Americans, so they could develop a virus to kill Chinese people.

;

;This sort of disinformation is so widespread in Taiwan that analysts have given it a moniker: ;yi mei lun;, or the “;US; scepticism” narrative. Its spread is becoming a major worry for Taiwan's government and civil society in the run-up to a hugely important presidential election next January. Taiwanese voters will in effect be asked to decide whether Taiwan should remain aligned with America in strengthening deterrence against a possible Chinese invasion, or should move towards building ties with China. The opposition Kuomintang has called the vote a choice between “war and peace”, implying that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's hostility towards China will provoke it to attack. Chinese state actors have backed that framing, spreading narratives that portray ;America;, not China, as the island's biggest threat. Much of the disinformation is intended to reinforce that false message.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Lo Ping-chen, a cabinet minister who since 2018 has been leading a government task force against disinformation, says it has “severely infiltrated” Taiwan's society. “We used to think there was more during election season. But it's now become normalised. It happens every day.” Most Taiwanese voters have little idea of this. A recent survey by Doublethink Lab, a Taiwanese group that studies disinformation, found that less than 20% of respondents believed the false information spread in Taiwan during elections came from abroad. Puma Shen, who heads Doublethink Lab, worries about the one-fifth of voters who are not aligned with any party and could be a decisive bloc. “Even if only 15% of voters are truly affected by Chinese disinformation, it takes only 7% of voters to change the election results,” he says.

;

;A recent study of ;US;-scepticism narratives by the Information Environment Research Centre, a Taiwanese research group, found Chinese actors were helping to spread most of them. But more than half appeared to have Taiwanese origins. That suggests China is “piggybacking” on fears in Taiwanese society, says Chihhao Yu, the report's author. He notes that many Taiwanese have an “orphan mentality”: they fear abandonment by outsiders because of Taiwan's experience of losing American diplomatic recognition in the 1970s.

;

;Chinese actors are exploiting those worries, just as Russian disinformation exploited America's racial and cultural cracks to help Donald Trump in 2016. Chinese disinformation also echoes Russian propaganda about the war in Ukraine, which claims America is behind the conflict (and is creating bioweapons in Ukrainian labs).

;

;China has developed systematic means to make falsehoods trend in Taiwan, says Chien Yu-yen, a former journalist and author of a book about Chinese influence on Taiwan's media. She points to a spurious claim that America “wants to blow up” ;TSMC, ;a Taiwanese chipmaker. It originated with a misleading video posted on Douyin, the Chinese version of TikTok, which featured an American lawmaker appearing to discuss the possibility. The following morning, a Taiwanese newspaper published a story about the video. Opposition lawmakers and talk-show hosts whipped up outrage. “The journey from China's Douyin to Taiwan's mass media, videos, newspapers and television took less than half a day,” says Ms Chien. Chinese state media amplified the narrative, as if merely commenting from the outside on a Taiwanese debate.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Taiwanese officials believe that many of the Taiwanese launching; US-;scepticism untruths are “local collaborators” taking orders and payments from China. But that is hard to prove, because the suspected Chinese funding is probably funnelled through Taiwanese businesspeople or public-relations firms. Wang Kun-yi, a local commentator who frequently writes ;US;-scepticism narratives for Chinese media and pro-China Taiwanese media, defends his work as a commercial enterprise. All journalists in Taiwan serve the bias of their newspapers' bosses, says Mr Wang, who has worked for both pro-independence and pro-unification newspapers. “Everyone just treats it as a job,” he says. “It's a tool to feed yourself.”

;

;Taiwan has laws against foreign infiltration and election influence, but they are limited to cases of proven state-sponsored activity. It has additional laws against spreading wilful falsehood in broadcast media, but they do not cover print or digital outlets. In 2020 the government revoked the licence of ;CTI ;News, a pro-China channel, citing repeated failures to verify information. ;CTI; simply moved online.

;

;The case sparked accusations of censorship, which Taiwan wants to avoid. So the government has resorted to more liberal methods of fighting disinformation. It has tried to improve media literacy, provide faster official clarifications and promote fact-checking organisations. But such means cannot match the speed of Chinese propaganda. In August Meta, which owns Facebook, removed a network of more than 7,000 accounts, pages and groups that were spreading Chinese disinformation. But new accounts are easy to set up, a problem that will only accelerate with artificial intelligence, says Mr Lo.

;

;Chinese disinformation has already distorted Taiwan's public conversation. Will it move votes? Meta has noted that the Chinese disinformation network it removed was “high volume, low reach”, despite having a veneer of engagement designed to make the accounts look more popular than they were. Studies of Russian disinformation in America have found that it has little impact on voter preferences. Despite all the messaging in Chinese and Taiwanese media against the Democratic Progressive Party, its candidate, William Lai, is leading in the polls. And for all the scepticism about America, Taiwanese are even warier of China. A 2022 survey by Academia Sinica, a Taiwanese research institution, found 34% of respondents agreeing that America is a “credible” country. Only 9% said the same of China.

;

;China is to blame. It recently surrounded Taiwan with warplanes and warships even as its ruling Communist Party unveiled an integration plan promising benefits to Taiwanese people living in Fujian, a southern province near the island. Most Taiwanese know where their real threat comes from. But China's insidious efforts to mislead them are increasing. ;■;

; Fri, 29 Sep 2023 05:27:02 +0800 Why Emmanuel Macron is pulling French troops out of Niger | Middle East & Africahttps://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/09/25/why-emmanuel-macron-is-pulling-french-troops-out-of-niger ;
;
;

;;W;;hen on; July 26th soldiers from Niger's presidential guard ;detained and overthrew; the leader they were supposed to be protecting, France insisted that it would not take orders from the new junta. When the coup leaders told France's ambassador and its 1,500 soldiers stationed in the country to get out, the ;former colonial power; dug in its heels, citing a point of democratic principle. Emmanuel Macron, the French president, declared that Mohamed Bazoum, Niger's captive president, had been democratically elected and so France would recognise only his authority.

;

;But in an abrupt reversal on September 24th, Mr Macron announced that not only was France's ambassador, Sylvain Itté, being recalled to Paris but all troops in Niger would leave by the end of the year. France, declared its president, would thus put an end to bilateral military co-operation with Niger.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The official explanation for this about-turn is that the new authorities “no longer want to fight against terrorism”, said Mr Macron. Between 2013 and 2022 France led an anti-jihadist operation in the countries of the Sahel—Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania and Niger—initiated at their request. Backed by other European countries, including Britain, Estonia and Sweden, the operation at its peak counted over 5,000 French soldiers. Last year France decided to wind down Operation Barkhane and quit Mali after military leaders there staged a second military coup, and hired mercenaries from Russia's Wagner group. French forces withdrew to what then seemed to be the relative stability of neighbouring Niger, where France maintains a military base, complete with fighter jets and Reaper drones.

;

;As it happens, Mr Macron has a point about counter-terrorism. Niger's junta justified its putsch in July as a response to rising insecurity. In reality political violence has surged since the coup leaders took over. According to the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project, a research group based in America, political violence increased by 42% in the first month of rule under the junta in Niger compared with the previous month. In the first six months of 2023, when Mr Bazoum held office, by contrast, it fell by 39% compared with the previous six months.

;

;Yet the French decision to quit Niger is about much more than this. It is partly a pragmatic recognition that the junta was not going to budge, and that regional countries, despite their threats, were unlikely to try to dislodge it from power. The decision also marks a reluctant and painful realisation in Paris that its influence on the continent has taken a severe knock.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In the eyes of a generation of younger Nigeriens, and partly thanks to the efficiency of Russian disinformation campaigns, France is now regarded as the problem, not the solution. In 2013 François Hollande, Mr Macron's predecessor, was feted in Bamako, Mali's capital, after he dispatched French troops to beat back a jihadist incursion. Today crowds wave hastily stitched Russian flags, and call for France to get out.

;

;The uncomfortable truth is that, however much the French point to their tactical successes in the Sahel, the broader picture since 2013 is one of spreading political violence. This has rapidly spilled over into West Africa's coastal states. Unlike other former colonial powers, France keeps a strong military presence on the continent, which consists of four other permanent bases, in Djibouti, Gabon, Ivory Coast and Senegal. This makes it a ready target to blame, and to accuse of neo-colonial occupation. The decision to leave Niger, declared the junta after Mr Macron's declaration, was a “historic moment” for the country's sovereignty.

;

;The weight of France's history casts a long shadow of suspicion over its broader activities on the continent. In a landmark speech in Burkina Faso in 2017, Mr Macron laid out his plans for a Franco-African reset. France would turn the page on “françafrique”, the web of cosy links between Paris and French-speaking African leaders that kept them in office and business deals flowing north. To make the point, he returned works of art from French museums, and asked forgiveness for France's role in the genocide in Rwanda. Yet this new approach, combined with its colonial past, means that France is held to standards not applied to other outside powers, including Russia, China and Turkey. America too attracts little dissent. It runs a drone base out of Agadez in Niger, and has quietly decided to stay despite the change of regime, to little outcry.

;

;France had no good options in Niger. Had its troops and diplomats stayed in spite of the junta's demands, this could have precipitated a nasty confrontation. By leaving, as François Heisbourg of the Foundation for Strategic Research in Paris, puts it, “France's bluff has been called, which we could pay a heavy price for down the line.” For France, a serious rethink of its Africa policy and the sustainability of its military presence on the continent is now in order. For the people of Niger, the likely consequence of this sorry episode is that political violence will only get worse. ;■;

; Thu, 28 Sep 2023 22:57:03 +0800 Some claim human lifespans can be lengthened indefinitely | Technology Quarterlyhttps://www.economist.com/technology-quarterly/2023/09/25/some-claim-human-lifespans-can-be-lengthened-indefinitely ;
;
;

;;T;;here is a ;story about a blues musician who, when questioned on his 100th birthday about his decades of smoking and drinking, responded that if he'd known he was going to live so long, he'd have taken better care of himself. Bryan Johnson is that apocryphal bluesman's polar opposite. He has been taking care of himself for years to a degree as remarkable, in its way, as the deepest devotion to bourbon and bad choices. By sacrificing the now for the future, rather than the other way around, he turns disposable-soma theory on its head.

;

;The daily regime which he and his many doctors have devised makes life in Biosphere 2 look sybaritic. A kilogram of vegetables, all before 11am, rigorous workouts lasting 45-60 minutes, and 100 pills, including metformin and rapamycin. His vital functions are subjected to the sort of continuous scrutiny more usually associated with laboratory animals. He says he is ageing at 69% of the normal rate.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Johnson, who has been described as the most measured man in the world, can afford the team of medics, trainers and dieticians who minister to him because selling Braintree, an electronic-payments company which he founded, left him with a net worth of more than $100m. For mere mortals, however, a range of less intensive options are available.

;

;One is a distillation of Mr Johnson's accumulated experience, available on his website as “Project Blueprint”. Though he makes it available for free, he says implementing it could cost $1,000-1,500 a month, including groceries, supplements, drugs and trainers.

;

;For those on a budget, or who would prefer to have their hands held, an entry-level product at around a tenth of that price is offered by Tally Health, based in New York. Tally is the latest brainchild of David Sinclair, who led early research on sirtuins. Members get a quarterly cheek-swab test to check levels of epigenetic methylation, thus providing a Horvath-clock-like age to compare with a client's chronological age, and a daily supplement containing fisetin, quercetin, resveratrol, spermidine and alpha-ketoglutarate, a molecule involved in several biochemical pathways which seems to give lab mice longer, healthier lives.

;

;Waiting in luxury

;

;For a more substantial fee, Human Longevity, in San Diego, offers customers full sequencing of their genomes and ;mri; scans of their bodies as well as a suite of other tests likely to leave them feeling like wired-up lab rats; for this they get a personal “longevity action plan” which the company will help them implement.

;

;;For now, people should concentrate on not dying as a means to the greater end of eventual age reversal;

;

;Human Longevity was founded in 2013 by Craig Venter, who, in the 1990s, ran a private rival to the Human Genome Project, and Peter Diamandis, a marketer, entrepreneur and all-round future-booster. Dr Venter later left, and though Mr Diamandis still has a stake in the business, his gaze seems to have shifted to a glitzier proposition. Fountain Life, his new venture, offers a similar package of goodies to that of Human Longevity, but with swimming pools and fluffy towels thrown in: “a country club for; precision diagnostics”, as it says in its marketing literature.

;

;Mr Diamandis's stated vision of the future goes like this. For now, people should concentrate on not dying. Not dying is an obvious end in itself, but in this context it is also a means to a further end. Not dying gets the customer through to the moment when senolytic drugs are proved and approved and ageing curtailed. That in turn sees them through to the ultimate goal: age reversal via epigenetic reprogramming.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This approach can be traced to the ideas of Aubrey de Grey, a computer scientist with a remarkable beard who has been active in the field since the 1980s. Through entities like the Methuselah Foundation and concepts like; SENS; (Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence) he did much to shape modern ideas about life extension while also providing some succour to those who saw it as a weird fringe pursuit. (Mr de Grey was relieved of his position at the ;SENS; Research Foundation in 2021 after allegations of sexual misconduct, all of which he denies). One of his pet ideas is “longevity escape velocity”, a future state where science is extending people's lifespans by more than a year every year.

;

;There is certainly room for scepticism about Mr Diamandis's attempts to sell people an inside track to that longed-for day. Even if the science were to come good quickly, the time it takes for new medical treatments to be approved tends to be measured in periods that will challenge the physiology of Fountain Life's more elderly customers. Excited talk of bringing ;ai; to bear on the matter (Fountain Life makes a hoo-ha about its use) has yet to produce much of a pudding, let alone one that provides any proof.

;

;Scepticism is increased by the number of defunct ideas and firms that litter the verges of the road to immortality. Human growth hormone, which is part of another nutrient-sensing pathway, was once promoted as having anti-ageing effects. Subsequent work on animals suggests using it might actually be counterproductive. The same may be true of some of the anti-oxidant approaches built on theories about mitochondrial-;DNA; damage.

;

;The excitement over resveratrol guttered. Companies founded with much fanfare have lapsed into obscurity. Calico Life Sciences, a subsidiary of Alphabet, which was the Altos of its day in 2013, has fallen completely out of the conversation. Grand science projects born of entanglements between the very wealthy and the not entirely mainstream do not always end well. Remember Biosphere 2.

;

;A reasonable tendency to short-term scepticism, though, should not preclude medium-term open-mindedness. There is now a serious interest in understanding the biological underpinnings of ageing. There are treatments available which can almost certainly be used to extend healthspans, and possibly even lifespans, even though a lack of formal trial evidence makes it hard to see which of the touted options actually work. And there are promising lines of inquiry which may lead to bigger breakthroughs.

;

;Evolution has no interest in seeing people live for ever, or even indefinitely. But that will not stop people trying. Whether it is feasible in practice is another thing altogether, for bodies contain trillions of cells that will need either rejuvenation or renewal. But less heroic measures towards smaller gains may yet yield fruit. And that alone is surely worth the effort. ;■;

;

;;;Correction (September 26th 2023);: This article has been changed. Tally Health uses a proprietary epigenetic clock, not the Horvath clock, for its epigenetic test.;

; Thu, 28 Sep 2023 18:57:02 +0800 India is testing America’s friendship | Asiahttps://www.economist.com/asia/2023/09/25/india-is-testing-americas-friendship ;
;

;;A;; WEEK HAS; passed since Canada's prime minister, Justin Trudeau, ;told Parliament; of “credible intelligence” linking India to the killing in June of a Canadian Sikh activist, Hardeep Singh Nijjar. In those few days, relations between Canada and India have gone from bad to worse. That is serious enough. But the bigger question is what might happen to America's till now rapidly ;deepening ties; with the South Asian giant.

;

;Many in India believe the Americans have hung Mr Trudeau out to dry. They note what appeared to be a fairly non-committal response to his allegation by the administration of President Joe Biden. Instead of fulsomely sounding the alarm, it merely expressed concern and called for India to co-operate with the Canadian investigation into the killing.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That perhaps stiffened the resolve of Narendra Modi's government to brazen the allegations out. India angrily denies them, even as it hints that, whoever did for Mr Nijjar, he had it coming. In this, many Indians cheer their government on. It had long branded the dead Canadian a terrorist for advocating a separate ;Sikh homeland; in Punjab and associating with violent groups dedicated to that cause. Indians grimly recall—as the West generally does not—the bloody insurgency and fierce repression this inspired, from the late 1970s to the early 1990s. It led to tens of thousands of deaths in Punjab and to the assassination in 1984 of Indira Gandhi, India's then prime minister, by her Sikh bodyguards.

;

;But Canada is now starting to look rather less isolated than Mr Trudeau's Indian critics assumed it was. It turns out that some of the intelligence pointing to Indian involvement in the killing was collected—and provided to the Canadians—by America. Both countries are part of the “Five Eyes” intelligence-sharing club that also includes Australia, Britain and New Zealand. Mr Biden and other Five Eyes leaders duly raised the killing in private with Mr Modi, earlier in September at the ;G;20 summit in Delhi. Mr Modi saw that confab as the latest great coming-out party for India. The Nijjar row has put a dampener on it.

;

;India probably underestimated the strength of Western solidarity. It viewed Canada as a second-order power: if the allegations were true, it felt able to meddle egregiously; if they were untrue, Canada's concerns could be dismissed out of hand. As Tanvi Madan of the Brookings Institution in Washington has noted, this was to underestimate the ties that bind America to Canada. The two countries are hand-in-glove security and intelligence allies as well as neighbours. The assassination also has implications for America's security. It cannot accept foreign-backed hitmen operating in North America. For that matter, there are Sikh communities in America, too.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;India is not the only country guilty of miscalculation. Canada has, as the Indians claim, long been too unconcerned about Sikh separatist firebrands operating on its soil. Their movement has few adherents in India these days; but Western countries underestimate the risk of the violence resuming. This blind spot survived even the blowing up of an Air India flight from Montreal to London in 1985. Yet if India thought this Canadian oversight justified it in unleashing its assassins, it was woefully naive.

;

;It now seems determined to defy its accusers over the assassination, even if any incriminating evidence is made public. In this it appears to assume America will not rupture its strategic ;commitment to India;. That is probably correct. The bilateral partnership, in India's defence, has little to do with the “shared democratic values” Mr Biden and other American politicians proclaim. America hardly criticises Mr Modi for the democratic backsliding he and his party have brought to India. The partnership is based on mutual concern over China.

;

;Still, the row over Mr Nijjar casts the relationship in sharper relief by highlighting what an awkward American partner India is. It is at once pro-Western and resentful of the West. It is eager to deepen security ties with America, yet deeply loth to cede any aspect of its security to another power. If India started throwing its weight about in ways reminiscent of China, it would quickly lose some of the bipartisan support it now enjoys in Washington. Mr Nijjar's death may in this respect come to look like a clarifying moment. If India was indeed responsible, as it seems America as well as Canada believes, Mr Modi should temper his defiance. ;■;
